problems.title: Shizuku Hoshikawa and Farm Legs
problems.statementHtml:
Kaori wants to spend the day with Shizuku! However, the zoo is closed, so they are visiting Farmer John's farm instead.

At Farmer John's farm, Shizuku counts nn legs. It is known that only chickens and cows live on the farm; a chicken has 22 legs, while a cow has 44.

Count how many different configurations of Farmer John's farm are possible. Two configurations are considered different if they contain either a different number of chickens, a different number of cows, or both.

Note that Farmer John's farm may contain zero chickens or zero cows.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains a single integer tt (1≤t≤1001≤t≤100)  — the number of test cases.

The only line of each test case contains a single integer nn (1≤n≤1001≤n≤100).
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output a single integer, the number of different configurations of Farmer John's farm that are possible.
problems.noteHtml:
For n=4n=4, there are two possible configurations of Farmer John's farm:

  • he can have two chickens and zero cows, or
  • he can have zero chickens and one cow.
It can be shown that these are the only possible configurations of Farmer John's farm.

For n=3n=3, it can be shown that there are no possible configurations of Farmer John's farm.

problems.title: Yuu Koito and Minimum Absolute Sum
problems.statementHtml:
Yuu is trying out the student council! Unfortunately, she is being forced to do clerical work... Touko wants her to fill out the blanks in various student council documents.

You are given a partially filled array of nonnegative integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an, where blank elements are denoted with −1−1. You would like to fill in the blank elements with nonnegative integers, such that the absolute value of the sum of the elements in its difference array is minimized.

More formally, let bb be the array of length n−1n−1 such that bi=ai+1−aibi=ai+1−ai for all 1≤i≤n−11≤i≤n−1. Find the minimum possible value of |b1+b2+⋯+bn−1||b1+b2+⋯+bn−1|, across all possible ways to fill in the blank elements of aa.

Additionally, output the array that achieves this minimum. If there are multiple such arrays, output the one that is lexicographically smallest∗∗.

∗∗For two arbitrary arrays cc and dd of length nn, we say that cc is lexicographically smaller than dd if there exists an index ii (1≤i≤n1≤i≤n) such that cj=djcj=dj for all j<ij<i, and ci<dici<di. In other words, cc and dd differ in at least one index, and at the first index at which they differ, cici is smaller than didi.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains a single integer tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104)  — the number of test cases.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (2≤n≤2⋅1052≤n≤2⋅105).

The second line of each test case contains nn integers, a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (−1≤ai≤106−1≤ai≤106).

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, on the first line, output the minimum possible value of |b1+b2+⋯+bn−1||b1+b2+⋯+bn−1|. Then, on the second line, output nn integers, the values of a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an in the lexicographically smallest array achieving this minimum.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first example, we fill in the array a=[2,0,7,1]a=[2,0,7,1], which yields the difference array b=[−2,7,−6]b=[−2,7,−6].

The absolute value of the sum of the elements in bb is 11. It can be proven that this is the minimum possible. Furthermore, it can be proven that this is the lexicographically smallest array aa that achieves this minimum.

problems.title: Renako Amaori and XOR Game (easy version)
problems.statementHtml:
This is the easy version of the problem. The only difference between the easy and hard versions is that in the easy version, ai,bi≤1ai,bi≤1.

Renako is stuck between a rock and a hard place... and by that, of course, I mean Ajisai and Mai! Both of them want to hang out with her, and she just can't decide! So Ajisai and Mai have decided to play the XOR game.

Ajisai and Mai are given arrays aa and bb of length nn (0≤ai,bi≤10≤ai,bi≤1). They will play a game that lasts for nn turns, where Ajisai moves on odd-numbered turns and Mai moves on even-numbered turns. On the ii-th turn, the player to move may choose to swap aiai and bibi, or pass.

Note that if a swap occurs, the index that is being swapped must match the turn number. For example, on the first turn, Ajisai may choose to swap a1a1 and b1b1, or pass. On the second turn, Mai may choose to swap a2a2 and b2b2, or pass. This continues for nn turns. Thus, only Ajisai can swap odd indices, and only Mai can swap even indices.

At the end of the game, Ajisai achieves a score of a1⊕a2⊕⋯⊕ana1⊕a2⊕⋯⊕an, and Mai achieves a score of b1⊕b2⊕⋯⊕bnb1⊕b2⊕⋯⊕bn∗∗. The player with the higher score wins. If the players have the same score, the game ends in a tie.

Determine the outcome of the game with optimal play. More formally, one player is considered to win with optimal play if there exists a strategy for them such that they always win, regardless of their opponent's choices. The game is considered a tie with optimal play if neither player has such a strategy.

∗∗⊕⊕ denotes the bitwise XOR operation
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains a single integer tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104)  — the number of test cases.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (1≤n≤2⋅1051≤n≤2⋅105).

The second line of each test case contains nn integers, a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (0≤ai≤10≤ai≤1).

The third line of each test case contains nn integers, b1,b2,…,bnb1,b2,…,bn (0≤bi≤10≤bi≤1).

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, output on a single line "Ajisai" if Ajisai wins with optimal play, "Mai" if Mai wins with optimal play, or "Tie" if the game ends in a tie with optimal play.

You may output the answer in any case (upper or lower). For example, the strings "mAi", "mai", "MAI", and "maI" will be recognized as "Mai".
problems.noteHtml:
In the first example, one way the game might play out is as follows:

On turn 1, Ajisai chooses to swap a1a1 and b1b1. Now the arrays are a=[1,0,0,1]a=[1,0,0,1] and b=[1,0,1,1]b=[1,0,1,1].

On turn 2, Mai chooses to pass.

On turn 3, Ajisai chooses to swap a3a3 and b3b3. Now the arrays are a=[1,0,1,1]a=[1,0,1,1] and b=[1,0,0,1]b=[1,0,0,1].

On turn 4, Mai chooses to swap a4a4 and b4b4. Now the arrays are a=[1,0,1,1]a=[1,0,1,1] and b=[1,0,0,1]b=[1,0,0,1].

Now, Ajisai's final score is 1⊕0⊕1⊕1=11⊕0⊕1⊕1=1 and Mai's final score is 1⊕0⊕0⊕1=01⊕0⊕0⊕1=0. Therefore, Ajisai wins the game.

It is not guaranteed that the above description is representative of optimal play.

problems.title: Renako Amaori and XOR Game (hard version)
problems.statementHtml:
This is the hard version of the problem. The only difference between the easy and hard versions is that in the hard version, ai,bi≤106ai,bi≤106.

Renako is stuck between a rock and a hard place... and by that, of course, I mean Ajisai and Mai! Both of them want to hang out with her, and she just can't decide! So Ajisai and Mai have decided to play the XOR game.

Ajisai and Mai are given arrays aa and bb of length nn (0≤ai,bi≤1060≤ai,bi≤106). They will play a game that lasts for nn turns, where Ajisai moves on odd-numbered turns and Mai moves on even-numbered turns. On the ii-th turn, the player to move may choose to swap aiai and bibi, or pass.

Note that if a swap occurs, the index that is being swapped must match the turn number. For example, on the first turn, Ajisai may choose to swap a1a1 and b1b1, or pass. On the second turn, Mai may choose to swap a2a2 and b2b2, or pass. This continues for nn turns. Thus, only Ajisai can swap odd indices, and only Mai can swap even indices.

At the end of the game, Ajisai achieves a score of a1⊕a2⊕⋯⊕ana1⊕a2⊕⋯⊕an, and Mai achieves a score of b1⊕b2⊕⋯⊕bnb1⊕b2⊕⋯⊕bn∗∗. The player with the higher score wins. If the players have the same score, the game ends in a tie.

Determine the outcome of the game with optimal play. More formally, one player is considered to win with optimal play if there exists a strategy for them such that they always win, regardless of their opponent's choices. The game is considered a tie with optimal play if neither player has such a strategy.

∗∗⊕⊕ denotes the bitwise XOR operation
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains a single integer tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104)  — the number of test cases.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (1≤n≤2⋅1051≤n≤2⋅105).

The second line of each test case contains nn integers, a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (0≤ai≤1060≤ai≤106).

The third line of each test case contains nn integers, b1,b2,…,bnb1,b2,…,bn (0≤bi≤1060≤bi≤106).

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, output on a single line "Ajisai" if Ajisai wins with optimal play, "Mai" if Mai wins with optimal play, or "Tie" if the game ends in a tie with optimal play.

You may output the answer in any case (upper or lower). For example, the strings "mAi", "mai", "MAI", and "maI" will be recognized as "Mai".
problems.noteHtml:
In the first example, one way the game might play out is as follows:

On turn 1, Ajisai chooses to swap a1a1 and b1b1. Now the arrays are a=[3,4,6,1]a=[3,4,6,1] and b=[1,2,3,7]b=[1,2,3,7].

On turn 2, Mai chooses to swap a2a2 and b2b2. Now the arrays are a=[3,2,6,1]a=[3,2,6,1] and b=[1,4,3,7]b=[1,4,3,7].

On turn 3, Ajisai chooses to pass.

On turn 4, Mai chooses to swap a4a4 and b4b4. Now the arrays are a=[3,2,6,7]a=[3,2,6,7] and b=[1,4,3,1]b=[1,4,3,1].

Now, Ajisai's final score is 3⊕2⊕6⊕7=03⊕2⊕6⊕7=0 and Mai's final score is 1⊕4⊕3⊕1=71⊕4⊕3⊕1=7. Therefore, Mai wins the game.

It is not guaranteed that the above description is representative of optimal play.

For additional examples, see the examples of the easy version.

problems.title: Rae Taylor and Trees (easy version)
problems.statementHtml:
This is the easy version of the problem. The only difference between the easy and hard versions is that the hard version asks you to construct an example of a satisfactory tree.

As an Earth mage, Rae has mastered the spell of growing trees! But Manaria brags that she can grow a more impressive species of trees. Rae remembers that the most rare type of tree can be grown using a formula represented by a certain permutation — please help her construct it!

You are given a permutation∗∗ pp of length nn.

Determine if there exists an undirected tree with nn vertices labeled 1,2,…,n1,2,…,n, satisfying the following condition:

∗∗A permutation of length nn is an array that contains every integer from 11 to nn exactly once, in any order.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains a single integer tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104)  — the number of test cases.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (2≤n≤2⋅1052≤n≤2⋅105).

The second line of each test case contains nn integers, p1,p2,…,pnp1,p2,…,pn (1≤pi≤n1≤pi≤n). It is guaranteed that all pipi are distinct.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, output on a single line "Yes" if there exists a tree satisfying the given condition, and "No" otherwise.

You may output the answer in any case (upper or lower). For example, the strings "yEs", "yes", "YES", and "yeS" will be recognized as "Yes".
problems.noteHtml:
In the first example, we can construct the tree with the following edges:

  • {3,1}{3,1},
  • {4,1}{4,1},
  • {6,5}{6,5},
  • {6,2}{6,2},
  • {6,1}{6,1}.

Then we have that

  • 1<31<3, and 11 appears before 33 in pp,
  • 1<41<4, and 11 appears before 44 in pp,
  • 5<65<6, and 55 appears before 66 in pp,
  • 2<62<6, and 22 appears before 66 in pp,
  • 1<61<6, and 11 appears before 66 in pp.

In the second example, it can be shown that there does not exist a tree satisfying the given constraints.

problems.title: Anisphia Wynn Palettia and Good Permutations
problems.statementHtml:
Anis and her new assistant Euphie are improving the Witch's Broom! Magicology requires great precision and care — in order to fly, the construction of the broom must have sufficiently few imperfections.

For an arbitrary array aa of length mm, call an index ii (1≤i≤m−21≤i≤m−2) bad if aiai, ai+1ai+1, and ai+2ai+2 are all pairwise coprime. More formally, ii is a bad index if and only if gcd(ai,ai+1)=gcd(ai,ai+2)=gcd(ai+1,ai+2)=1gcd(ai,ai+1)=gcd(ai,ai+2)=gcd(ai+1,ai+2)=1∗∗. Furthermore, call aa good if it has at most 66 bad indices.

You are given an integer nn. Construct a good permutation†† pp of length nn. It can be shown that such a permutation always exists.

Note that you do not have to minimize the number of bad indices.

∗∗gcd(x,y)gcd(x,y) denotes the greatest common divisor of xx and yy

†† A permutation of length nn is an array that contains every integer from 11 to nn exactly once, in any order.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains a single integer tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104)  — the number of test cases.

The only line of each test case contains a single integer nn (3≤n≤2⋅1053≤n≤2⋅105).

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output on a single line nn integers p1,p2,…,pnp1,p2,…,pn, an example of a good permutation of length nn. If there are multiple good permutations, you may output any of them.
problems.noteHtml:
For n=9n=9, we have

iipipipi+1pi+1pi+2pi+2gcd(pi,pi+1)gcd(pi,pi+1)gcd(pi,pi+2)gcd(pi,pi+2)gcd(pi+1,pi+2)gcd(pi+1,pi+2)
11554488111144
22448811441111
33881199111111
44119933111133
55993366333333
66336622331122
77662277221111

The only bad index is 33. Since 1≤61≤6, pp is a good permutation.

problems.title: Rae Taylor and Trees (hard version)
problems.statementHtml:
This is the hard version of the problem. The only difference between the easy and hard versions is that the hard version asks you to construct an example of a satisfactory tree.

As an Earth mage, Rae has mastered the spell of growing trees! But Manaria brags that she can grow a more impressive species of trees. Rae remembers that the most rare type of tree can be grown using a formula represented by a certain permutation — please help her construct it!

You are given a permutation∗∗ pp of length nn.

Determine if there exists an undirected tree with nn vertices labeled 1,2,…,n1,2,…,n, satisfying the following condition:

Additionally, if there exists such a tree, output any of them.

∗∗A permutation of length nn is an array that contains every integer from 11 to nn exactly once, in any order.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains a single integer tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104)  — the number of test cases.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (2≤n≤2⋅1052≤n≤2⋅105).

The second line of each test case contains nn integers, p1,p2,…,pnp1,p2,…,pn (1≤pi≤n1≤pi≤n). It is guaranteed that all pipi are distinct.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, output on a single line "Yes" if there exists a tree satisfying the given condition, and "No" otherwise.

Then, if the answer is "Yes", output n−1n−1 lines. The ii-th of these lines should contain two integers uu and vv, denoting an edge connecting vertices uu and vv.

You may output the answer in any case (upper or lower). For example, the strings "yEs", "yes", "YES", and "yeS" will be recognized as "Yes".
problems.noteHtml:
In the first example, we can construct the tree given in the sample output. We have that

  • 1<31<3, and 11 appears before 33 in pp,
  • 1<41<4, and 11 appears before 44 in pp,
  • 5<65<6, and 55 appears before 66 in pp,
  • 2<62<6, and 22 appears before 66 in pp,
  • 1<61<6, and 11 appears before 66 in pp.

In the second example, it can be shown that there does not exist a tree satisfying the given constraints.

problems.title: Sakura Adachi and Optimal Sequences
problems.statementHtml:
Adachi is in the middle of a generational crashout... over, uh, this problem! Yep, that's definitely it... anyways, please help her solve it!

You are given two arrays aa and bb of length nn (1≤ai≤bi1≤ai≤bi).

In one operation, you may either:

Let xx denote the minimum number of operations needed to make a=ba=b. Two arrays aa and bb of length nn are considered equal if ai=biai=bi for all 1≤i≤n1≤i≤n.

Find the value of xx. Additionally, count the number of sequences of operations that make a=ba=b using exactly xx operations. Two such sequences of operations are considered different if, for any 1≤j≤x1≤j≤x, the jj-th operation of each sequence differs (either in the type of operation selected or the index chosen, if applicable).

Since the number of sequences may be large, output it modulo 106+3106+3. Note that 106+3106+3 is a prime number.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains a single integer tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104)  — the number of test cases.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (2≤n≤2⋅1052≤n≤2⋅105).

The second line of each test case contains nn integers, a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤1061≤ai≤106).

The third line of each test case contains nn integers, b1,b2,…,bnb1,b2,…,bn (ai≤bi≤106ai≤bi≤106).

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output two integers, the value of xx, and the number of sequences of operations that make a=ba=b using exactly xx operations, modulo 106+3106+3. The value of xx should be printed exactly; that is, it should not be taken modulo 106+3106+3.
problems.noteHtml:
In the second sample, it is possible to convert aa into bb using only three operations. There is only one way to do so, namely:

  • Add 11 to a1a1, yielding a=[2,1]a=[2,1]. Then double all elements of aa, yielding a=[4,2]a=[4,2]. Then add 11 to a2a2, yielding a=[4,3]a=[4,3]. Then we have that a=ba=b, as desired.

It can be shown that it is impossible to convert aa into bb using fewer than three operations.

problems.title: Shiori Miyagi and Maximum Array Score
problems.statementHtml:
For the cost of 5000 yen, Miyagi can ask Sendai to do whatever she wants! Today, Miyagi demands that Sendai make her an array... specifically, Miyagi only wants a very particular type of array.

For arbitrary integers b≥2b≥2 and x≥1x≥1, define v(b,x)v(b,x) to be the maximal kk satisfying bk∣xbk∣x; that is, the maximal kk such that xx is a multiple of bkbk. It can be shown that this is always a well-defined, nonnegative integer.

You are given integers nn and mm satisfying n≤mn≤m. Find the maximum value of ∑ni=2v(i,ai)∑i=2nv(i,ai) across all arrays aa of length nn satisfying the following conditions:
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains a single integer tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104)  — the number of test cases.

The only line of each test case contains two integers nn and mm (2≤n≤m≤2⋅1052≤n≤m≤2⋅105).

It is guaranteed that the sum of mm over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output a single integer, the maximum value of ∑ni=2v(i,ai)∑i=2nv(i,ai) across all arrays aa of length nn satisfying the given conditions.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first example, one possible array is a=[6,8,9,16]a=[6,8,9,16] which yields a value of 3+2+2=73+2+2=7.

It can be shown that this is the maximum value of ∑ni=2v(i,ai)∑i=2nv(i,ai) across all arrays aa of length nn satisfying the given conditions.

tutorial.contentHtml:
I hope you all enjoyed the contest! Special thanks to

  • djm03178 for suggesting the inclusion of C1, and for helping with test writing on all problems, especially F
  • satyam343 for helping me solve H
  • Dominater069 for providing the idea for one of the solutions to E
  • Intellegent for providing one of the proofs for the solution to D, and for providing the idea for one of the solutions to F
